questions.title: Hello World
questions.description: Print the text `Hello, World!` to the console.
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'Hello World'. Include a main function with a comment saying 'Your code here', and any necessary boilerplate to run the program. Return only the code, no explanation.

questions.title: Variable Types
questions.description: Declare one variable of each type below and print them each on a separate line: an integer with value 42, a float with value 3.14, a string with value 'Alice', and a boolean with value true.
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'Variable Types'. Include a main function with a comment saying 'Declare and print variables here' and any necessary boilerplate. Do not pre-declare the variables. Return only the code, no explanation.

questions.title: Arithmetic Operations
questions.description: Given a = 10 and b = 3, print the result of addition, subtraction, multiplication, integer division, and modulo each on its own line.
constraints: Use integer division, not float division
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'Arithmetic Operations'. Include a main function with a comment saying 'Declare a=10, b=3 and print operations here'. Do not pre-declare the variables. Include necessary boilerplate and return only the code.

questions.title: String Concatenation
questions.description: Given s1 = 'Hello' and s2 = 'World', print them joined with a space, then print the length of the resulting string.
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'String Concatenation'. Include a main function with necessary imports and a comment 'Your code here'. Do not pre-declare the strings. Return only the code.

questions.title: Constants
questions.description: Declare a constant PI with value 3.14159 and a constant MAX with value 100. Print both on separate lines.
constraints: Use the idiomatic constant declaration syntax of the language
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'Constants'. Include a main function and a comment 'Declare constants and print here'. Return only the code.

questions.title: If / Else
questions.description: Given x = 15, print 'positive' if x is greater than 0, 'negative' if less than 0, or 'zero' if equal to 0.
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'If / Else'. Include a main function and a comment 'Declare x=15 and implement logic here'. Do not provide the if/else skeleton. Return only the code.

questions.title: FizzBuzz
questions.description: Loop through numbers 1 to 20. Print 'FizzBuzz' if divisible by both 3 and 5, 'Fizz' if divisible by 3 only, 'Buzz' if divisible by 5 only, or the number itself otherwise.
questions.example_output:
1
2
Fizz
4
Buzz
Fizz
7
8
Fizz
Buzz
11
Fizz
13
14
FizzBuzz
16
17
Fizz
19
Buzz
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'FizzBuzz'. Include a main function with a comment 'Implement loop and FizzBuzz logic here'. Do not provide the loop structure. Return only the code.

questions.title: While Loop
questions.description: Use a while loop to print the powers of 2 from 2^0 to 2^9, one per line.
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'While Loop'. Include a main function and a comment 'Implement while loop here'. Do not pre-declare counters or loop structures. Return only the code.

questions.title: Switch / Match Statement
questions.description: Given day = 'Wednesday', use a switch or match statement to print 'Weekday' for Monday through Friday, 'Weekend' for Saturday and Sunday, and 'Unknown' for anything else.
constraints: Use a switch or match statement, not if/else chains
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'Switch / Match Statement'. Include a main function and a comment 'Declare day and implement switch/match here'. Do not provide the case blocks. Return only the code.

questions.title: Break and Continue
questions.description: Loop through numbers 1 to 10. Skip the number 5 using continue. Stop the loop entirely when you reach 8 using break. Print each number that is processed.
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'Break and Continue'. Include a main function and a comment 'Implement loop with break/continue here'. Return only the code.

questions.title: Basic Function
questions.description: Write a function add(a, b) that returns the sum of two integers. Call it with (7, 5) and (-3, 3) and print the results.
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'Basic Function'. Include an empty main function that prints the result of calling an 'add' function with (7,5) and (-3,3). Provide a comment 'Define add function here'. Do not implement the function body. Return only the code.

questions.title: Default Parameters
questions.description: Write a function power(base, exponent) where exponent defaults to 2. Call it as power(3), power(3, 3), and power(2, 8) and print the results.
constraints: Use the language's native default parameter syntax
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'Default Parameters'. Include an empty main function with calls to power(3), power(3,3), and power(2,8). Provide a comment 'Define power function with default parameter here'. Return only the code.

questions.title: Recursive Factorial
questions.description: Write a recursive function factorial(n) that returns n!. Call it with 0, 6, and 10 and print the results.
constraints: Do not use standard library factorial functions
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'Recursive Factorial'. Include a main function with the necessary print calls and a comment 'Define recursive factorial function here'. Return only the code.

questions.title: Multiple Return Values
questions.description: Write a function min_max(numbers) that returns both the minimum and maximum of a list without using built-in min/max. Call it with [4, 1, 9, 3, 7] and print in the format 'Min: 1, Max: 9'.
constraints: Do not use built-in min() or max() functions
questions.starter_code_prompt: Generate starter code in {language} for a question titled 'Multiple Return Values'. Include a main function that calls min_max with [4,1,9,3,7] and a comment 'Define min_max function here'. Return only the code.
